entry.summary: A deep dive into how the partnership between developer and Artificial Intelligence transformed a weeks-long project into hours Recently, I embarked on an ambitious project: creating a complete dashboard for project and task management. What would traditionally take weeks of solo development was completed in a matter of hours thanks to strategic collaboration with AI. This article explores not only the technical outcome, but primarily how the synergy between human experience and AI computational capability can revolutionize software development. entry.title: Quick Guide: Create Your Account ID on Orderly
entry.summary:
Introduction
In this tutorial, you‚Äôll learn how to generate your Orderly Account ID ‚Äî a crucial step to authenticate yourself and use their private APIs. Before you can sign requests or integrate trading features with Orderly, you need this unique identifier linked to your wallet and the broker you‚Äôre working with. We‚Äôll go over what Orderly is, why the Account ID matters, and how to generate it step by step using JavaScript. Orderly is a decentralized trading infrastructure (DEX infra) that combines the efficiency of a centralized exchange (CEX) with the transparency and self-custody of DeFi. It doesn‚Äôt have its own user interface; instead, it provides an order engine and a liquidity layer that can be easily integrated by other projects. Thanks to its modular design, developers can buil‚Ä¶

entry.title: React Router v7 Remains Strong: Clarity After the ‚ÄúWake up, Remix!‚Äù Announcement
entry.summary: The recent announcement titled "Wake up, Remix!" has sparked a lot of reactions across the developer community. It‚Äôs natural to have questions about the future of Remix and React Router. But here‚Äôs the key point: React Router v7 is a stable, production-ready platform backed by a committed team that will continue maintaining and improving it. React Router v7 was designed to offer a robust and up-to-date experience. This version includes many of the advanced features that made Remix stand out, such as: Server-side rendering (SSR) and static site generation (SSG): Enabling faster, SEO-friendly applications. Simplified data loading and server actions: Making it easier to manage data and forms in a declarative way. These features make React Router v7 a strong choice for building modern applicat‚Ä¶

entry.title: Building Real-Time Applications with SignalR and C#
entry.summary:
Building Real-Time Applications with SignalR and C
In the ever-evolving world of web development, real-time capabilities are no longer just a luxury‚Äîthey‚Äôve become an essential feature of many modern applications. Whether you‚Äôre building a live chat system, a stock price tracker, or a multiplayer game, users expect instantaneous updates without refreshing the page. Enter SignalR, a powerful library that makes real-time communication in .NET applications not only possible but also surprisingly simple. In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore how to build interactive, real-time web applications using SignalR and C#. We‚Äôll dive into WebSockets, data streaming, and creating responsive user experiences. By the end, you‚Äôll have a solid foundation to start building your own real-time applications. At i‚Ä¶

entry.title: Getting Started with Traits and Trait Bounds
entry.summary:
Getting Started with Traits and Trait Bounds in Rust
In Rust, traits are the secret sauce that powers polymorphism, code reusability, and generic programming without sacrificing performance. If you‚Äôve ever wondered how Rust achieves its blend of safety, expressiveness, and speed, you‚Äôll find that traits play a starring role. In this post, we‚Äôll demystify traits and trait bounds, break them down with practical examples, and help you leverage their full potential in your Rust code. By the end of this blog, you‚Äôll not only understand what traits are and how they work but also how to use them effectively to write clean, reusable, and idiomatic Rust code. Let‚Äôs dive in! A trait in Rust is a collection of methods that define shared behavior. You can think of traits as interfaces in other langu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Running on a Treadmill Set to ‚ÄúImpossible‚Äù: My Self-Taught Dev Rant
entry.summary: I can‚Äôt be the only one who feels like they‚Äôve been running on a treadmill set to ‚Äúimpossible.‚Äù I clocked over 600 hours teaching myself HTML, CSS, and JavaScript after high school‚Äîbuilt small projects, watched more than 80 tutorials, even wrestled with my first React component. I thought: ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm on my way.‚Äù Then I open job boards and see ‚ÄúMERN + AI/ML‚Äù plastered everywhere. ‚ÄúMust have 3‚Äì5 years‚Äô experience integrating machine learning.‚Äù Almost every hackathon in Kenya now has ‚ÄúAI‚Äù in the title, and I‚Äôm left wondering whether I should drop everything, learn Python overnight, and become a data scientist‚Äîdespite being only in my second year of uni and having barely scratched the surface of front-end, not to mention back-end. Don‚Äôt get me wrong‚ÄîI love what I do. I still geek out when a CS‚Ä¶

entry.title: How I Fixed a Client's Slow Website by Just Deleting Spaces (True Story)
entry.summary: So last month, I get this call from Sania. She's practically in tears because her jewelry store website is dying. Sales dropped 40%, people are leaving her site immediately, and she just wasted $5,000 on some "SEO guru" who did absolutely nothing. I open up her website code, and honestly? I couldn't believe what I was seeing. It was a complete mess. The previous developer left behind comments from 2021, spaces everywhere, and so much unnecessary junk that it was painful to look at. Here's the crazy part - it took me about an hour to fix, and her website speed went from terrible to actually good. Two weeks later, way fewer people were leaving her site right away. I'm sharing this story because everyone's obsessing over fancy new tools while ignoring the simple stuff that actually works. Wha‚Ä¶

entry.title: Unit Tests... When and Where?ü§îüß™
entry.summary: Over the past few weeks, we've been restructuring our marketplace. We basically had to rebuild the project from scratch to support new business rules and migrate our database from NoSQL to SQL ‚Äî all without affecting the production environment experience. Our CI/CD pipeline includes automated analysis with SonarQube to catch bugs, vulnerabilities, duplicated code, test coverage, and more. Up to that point ‚Äî everything‚Äôs great! But then‚Ä¶ the pipeline started failing a few times due to unit test coverage falling below the expected 70% threshold. The problem? The uncovered areas included things like DbContext, repository classes, and even some domain entities ‚Äî areas that, according to best practices, shouldn't be the main focus of unit testing. The danger of chasing high test coverage at all costs is that you end up testing things outside of your business logic ‚Äî like framework behavior, library internals, and implementation details that are likely to change. ‚úÖ Focus on testing what matters: the behavior and rules of your business. Code with purpose. Test with strategy. Deploy with confidence. üëâ Here‚Äôs an article where Martin Fowler explains this much better: https://martinfowler.com/bliki/TestCoverage.html
